Let me qualify my recommendation to start: if you're a fan of the Alien franchise who finds the horror genre enjoyable, this game should scratch that itch unlike anything before. If not, maybe you want to read a little more, maybe from me, maybe from some one else.   TL;DR: It has the same kind of atmosphere and building dread that the original film had (which is not for the impatient fans of the horror genre - you're going to have to give it time to break you down). The story is a safe Alien film from what I know, which is a mixed blessing. Minigames are hit or miss in mingling with the survival. Get a controller with vibration and surround capable audio and the immersion factor increases drastically!  ***Of minor note, I had to upgrade my GPU drivers in order to smooth out some issues with the game. If you're having trouble, this is a good first step!  Speaking from a point of view 6 hours into the storyline, I find myself compelled at this time to write a review based on my experience. Let me say, that this game gets my adrenaline going and my heart pounding. I'm the kind of gamer who tends to lose themself in the game, taking on the role of the protagonist - in this case, it means that I am extremely cautious and methodical in my approach to the game.  The atmosphere of this game is an absolutely brutal, slow burning, and nervewracking playthrough. Tension is almost constantly being plucked, and every time I feel comfortable with a decision to move or hide, walking through the next doorway or vent I am immediately confronted by some part of the game (my motion tracker, a sight, a sound, even Ripley coughing or making a remark) that tightens that tension right back up and makes me immediately uncomfortable again. This is exactly what I expect from not just horror games, but the Alien franchise - yes there is the occaisional jump scare, but the majority of the tension arises from a constant build of dread. Each save point feels like a milestone to me, and a brief wave of relief washes over me each time I use one. I absolutely recommend a controller with a vibration function for this game, and surround sound - this is the kind of sensory assault these features were built for!!!  The story is one that I have expected so far, consistent and safe as far as the franchise is concerned. Amanda is generally likable to me, and while her attitude is very reminiscent of Ellen Ripley's characterization, she isn't quite as confident or focused as her mother. It adds to her vulnerability I think, which is exactly what the developers were aiming for in this game. Bravo for making her her own character, but reminding me of what I loved in the movies! The rest of the supporting cast have been kind of 'meh' so far, but the company seems to be acting unusual in many ways, though many of those elements have yet to play out for me.  The minigames and interactivity outside general survival seem a little jagged. I don't think it detracts from the overall experience, and sometimes they're a nice break from constantly being on the defensive. Other times, however, I've found them actually adding to the urgency of situations, so I think they belong overall.

Initially I played this game for a few hours and hit pretty much every problem you could possibly hit. I wrote it off as poorly designed with terrible AI.  Then, some weeks later, I went back to it. And I loved it.  Pros ----- - The old school low-fi sci-fi art aesthetic is just fantastic. - Amanda Ripley is a great (almost Freeman-esque) protagonist who thinks (not shoots) her out of problems. - The voice acting is excellent. - Two of the enemy types (no spoilers here) have fantastic AI and are terrifying opponents.  Cons ----- - The human enemies are dire. Their AI is awful and really breaks the immersion of the game. It would have been infinitely better if they had been removed and the only other humans you heard/saw were through glass or on the radio. Honestly I've had moments where I'd sprint right up to 'bad guys' and it takes them 15-20 seconds to react when I'm 3 inches from their face. Randomly some of them don't even acknowledge you at all. - There is basically nothing in the way of tutorials. Even after trying to Google the purpose of the Rewire functions most people online seem unsure or conflicted about what they actually do. A lot of the items and more nuanced mechanics are only explained if you happen to glimpse the right Tool Tip on the loading screen...  Summary ---------- There's nothing out there really like this game and although CA tripped up with a few things you can't argue it's a fantastic bit of stealth gaming, a good story and abrilliant homage to Ridley Scott's movie.  Recommendations ----------------------- - Play it on HARD! The difficulty below that is just dull. - If you get frustrated that you've done the same bit too many times, QUIT! Honestly, come back to it another time and you'll probably breeze through it, this game rewards patience.

I am a fan of the Horror-Survival genre. I have been a fan since the very first Resident Evil when the dogs jumped through the hallway windows and scared the living BA-JEEESus! outta me! In fact, I also love me some good horror movies to boot; Alien being one of my favorites. So I had to try this game when it came out. It promised scares like the first Alien movie and was a different kind of 'Alien' game. And what it promised, it delivered like a parasite bursting out of a morbidly obese paunch. This is by-far and bar-none the best horror-survival game I have ever played to date. It really is that good.   New AI was developed for the Alien, that makes it a formidable foe. You can't fight it to start, because it is just too powerful, so you must avoid it. So how do you avoid it? You must be patient and you must listen. This game is visually stunning and is complimented by its sound track . You'll live to hear the franchise musical queues that are scaterred through-out the game. And when you hear the Alien drop down in the room next to you, your blood will run cold. The atmosphere pulls you into this world and the interesting puzzles, and game play keep you interested.   This is the first review I've ever taken the time to write, so think about that.   If you see this game on sale, definitely buy it.   If you were thinking about getting it, DOEET NAO.   Gaming Tips /w Possible spoilers:  - Start out by just crawling to move around. This method of travel is slow, but it'll afford you a lot less aggro-problems. If the Alien doesn't hear you, he won't come looking for you. - Be careful of what your walking on, as some surfaces make more noise than others. - Keep your head up kid; look to the vents you may see drool dripping down O.o - The robots (Working Joes) are really tuff and it makes more sense just to avoid them in the beginning. - The most efficient way to kill a robot; stun it with either a flash-bang and then wack it in the head (5+ times) with your wrench. The gun is only meant for humans. - Don't give up, because eventually you do get a weapon that affects the Alien (scares it away for a bit)

Put simply I ended up either being stressed about being hunted or bored with hiding in lockers and doing the same sort of quests in the same looking corridors. That's a little harsh perhaps and maybe I should have played it at a lower difficulty to have more fun and require less patience (I played on hard).   The first opening hour I was blown away, I really felt I was taking part in my own Alien movie (which by the way, is one of my favourite movies). I also enjoyed learning about the Seegson Corporation, I thought that part of the story was really interesting and their cheap androids quite terrifying. The sound is excellent, the graphics crisp and when the alien makes its first appearance it really is extremely tense indeed (I had to pause the game and actually considered just shutting my PC down! :-).   But alas after that, I just lost interest. I wasn't enjoying myself. I got tired of creeping from one bunch of locked doors to another, hiding in lockers and staring at a motion tracker as the most interesting aspects of the story dwindled away.   I am aware the majority of people don't feel the same way as I and overall the excellent opening hours made it an experience worth my time and money.  7.5/10

An exceptional survival horror game, perhaps the best title in its genre to be released so far. A truly harrowing, nerve-breaking and extremely tense experience, which manages to keep your fear alive all throughout and constantly feeds it with new catalysts. Perhaps its strongest point is that you are never actually safe in the game. Whether you are under a desk or hiding in locker, you're still very vulnerable. Its impressive gameplay and extremely realistic (note the paradox) environment make up for its rather shallow storyline and characters.  Since I thoroughly enjoyed this game, you will notice I will try to explain the cons more than I do the pros, since the latter are more obvious.  Pros: +excellent and extremely realistic atmosphere. Having all those buttons around with fancy names really makes you feel like a brainless monkey, as you would expect a good Sci-fi game to do. But, in the same time, it also manages to be pretty intuitive most of the time. +very serious scares and tension +intelligent and perceptive AI  +smart crafting system, which is often the key to survival +intelligent and intuitive gameplay overall: motion tracker, lots of places to hide, terminals to check, systems to reboot, vent system etc +a very well-made sound system, which makes up a lot of the game's atmosphere +lovely graphics, especially in the moments you're looking out into space  Cons: -the story isn't very original or complex. Even though it is tense and interesting most of the time, it's mostly just for the action. -character models are very similar. For a game with such excellent graphics, it's really disappointing to see the lack of detail the characters are condemned to. -a lot of technical objectives, which sometimes require you to go from one place to another without revealing anything significant for the story. At some point, I even forgot what I was there to do. But, as I mentioned previously, the story isn't exactly the game's focus. -some repetitive level design. You may or may not see this as a problem, since, as I said before, Sevastopol station does manage to be very realistic. But most places are pretty hard to tell apart from others and, without the map and the indicators, you'd probably be lost completely.  Overall, I'd say it deserves a 9/10. It is actually one of the best survival horror games I ever got to play.

This is the game that true fans of the franchise owe to themselves to play. As has been said over and over, the visuals and atmosphere absolutely nail the look and feel of Ridley Scott's 1979 classic horror/sci-fi film. Taking place on board a run down space station orbiting a gas giant you play as Amanda Ripley, Ellen Ripley's grown up daughter. She has been drawn here because of her ongoing search for the whereabouts of her mother. It seems that the doomed Nostromo's flight recorder has be found and is at Sevastapol station, an outer rim base owned by Seegson Corporation (a low rent competitor to Weyland Yutani).    From the moment you arrive, the immediate sense of dread is like a smothering wet blanket. Throughout the game you will be relentlessly hunted by the malevolent alien as you try to survive and stay one step ahead by any and all means available to you. Making matters worse, the remaining human survivors are generally hostile and tend to shoot first and ask questions later. Add to this the malfunctioning androids, called Working Joes and you have a trifecta of foes to contend with. Then there is the station itself which is old and on the verge of being decommissioned. Sevastapol constantly thwarts you with areas that are unsurmountable and doors that don't work, requiring you to often take alternate routes and find other ways to accomplish goals.   Much has been made of the alien and it's AI. This thing actively hunts you and it's terrifying as you cower in the dark listening to it stomping around and growling. It has finely tuned hearing and will come looking for you if you make noise. If it sees a door opening or closing it will likely come and investigate. As well, the alien can and does use the ventilation ducts to move around so you are never sure as you sneak along darkened corridors whether it will drop out of a ceiling duct ahead or behind you. Fortunately you are given a motion tracker early on that helps you to determine where your enemies are relative to you. You must learn to move quietly and decisively, while remaining malleable with the fluid nature of the situation. You can hide under furniture and inside lockers but sometimes the alien finds you anyway. Save stations will let you save your progress, but they are spread out and death often means having to play areas over again, increasing the tension even more. This is not a run and gun game, and early on you will find that trying to play it that way rewards you with death and death after death.   You have a number of tools at your disposal, like noisemakers and flares to distract the alien, but these will only draw it's attention away from you briefly and if you use them too often it will learn to ignore them. As well, you will be able to make molotovs that will scare the alien off briefly (it hates fire). You can also craft bombs and EMP devices and will find several firearms like a shotgun and a pistol. Those work well against humans and robots, but the noise of gun fire draws the aliens like a moth to a flame. The only weapon that is truly effective against the alien is a flamethrower which you find several chapters into the game. Unfortunately it's fuel burns up quickly and, depending on the difficulty setting, resources can be few and far between. Basically, you never truly feel safe at any time.   The audio design ensures that every creak and rattle of the station keeps you on edge and you will never get used to the sound of the alien crawling around in the ventilation system. Eventually you learn to interpret the different sounds that the alien makes and use it to your advantage but you can never be absolutely sure that your next move is going to be the right one. Many of the sound effects and musical cues are straight out of the 1979 movie making for a thoroughly absorbing soundscape.   The look of the game is just spectacular. Level design is well thought out and the environments are insanely detailed with lighting that is astonishingly realisitic. Over and over again I marvelled at the art direction and how well it matched up to the 1979 film. You can tell that the game designers are huge fans of Alien and it shows. There are numerous nods towards the original movie as you play through that will put a smile on your face. Little things like the drinking birds you find on tables here and there or the authentic looking space suits you see hanging in lockers create a wonderful sense of nostalgia.    Minor gripes: It has been said that the game is too long and I would agree with that statement somewhat. The last few missions contain too many twists and the goal posts keep getting moved further and further back. As well, these latter sections begin to chafe on you as you are required to return to previously cleared areas to activate a generator or throw a switch to open a door or power up machinery somewhere else. It's doesn't spoil the game, but it does begin to feel a bit same-old, same-old towards the end. Add to that a anti-climactic ending that screams for a sequel that we are never likely to get.    Still, this is a marvellous game, obviously make with love. Any fan of the original film or the alien franchise in general should buy it. The designers suggest that the game be played on hard setting, which I did. Resources are much more scarce, you must be more quiet to avoid drawing the aliens attention and the Alien is more omnipresent. If you can endure the entire game on this difficulty setting, you'll be rewarded with the Survivor achievement, something only 5% of players can boast about according to the global statistics. Good luck, youi'll need it...

This review is very late, but so are all the good things in life.   I did not think I would ever get to relive the sheer terror of Alien. But then this game came along. Holy ♥♥♥♥.  **SPOLIER ALERT**  You are Amanda Ripley, daughter of Ellen Ripley - the sole survivor of the horror aboard the Nostromo. The Weyland-Yutani Corporation has just found some evidence explaning your mother's disappearance and you are keen to get your hands on it. So you head onto the Sevastopol station, with its previous generation androids, sprawling space visuals, atmospheric retro future tech and a hulking, stalking Xenomorph.  Sevastopol is vast, sparsely populated and entirely eerie. You can feel the titular isolation on board Sevastopol. The survivors have banded together and formed factions in order to, well, survive. You have to maneuver, dodge, kill and run away from the survivors and the androids. Let me be frank, the scariest part of Sevastopol is not the Xenomorph. It's those damn androids. They are silent, entirely without expression and very god damn scary. Did I mention that they are also very hard to kill? Well, until you get the right gear for the job.   Then there's the alien itself. It is an efficient stalker. It learns your weapons, your hiding patterns and the more you use distracting tools, the more desensitized it becomes. That is scary. Until you get your hands on the flamethrower and even after, you continue to realise how under matched you are against this enemy, the perfect hunter.  The graphics are superb. The atmosphere manages to capture and convey the retro-future feel of the Alien movie. There is a film grain filter which may annoy some people, but you can obviously turn it off. Dead bodies feel real, the Alien is gloriously modelled and rendered with high detail textures. It's a visual experience.  The gameplay circles between active stealth and action. Both these elements mix into creating an odd 'survival' gameplay format, which is immensely rewarding. The stalking and sudden appearances of the Alien help in making the somewhat repetitive portions of the game immensely interesting. Hearing the painful death throes of other survivors as the Alien mows into them can be very scary.  The narrative is insanely compelling. Reading emails you find around Sevastopol draws you further into the murky side of the space station. The lack of ethics of mega corporations is a theme that gradually establishes itself into the narrative.  All in all, this is the first horror-survival game that I have truly enjoyed, which is a visual treat and has a compelling, attention holding narrative.  9/10 - would recommend.

This is the Alien game you have been waiting for!  For once the Xenomorph is given proper respects as the unstoppable killing machine it is designed to be. You really feel powerless and hopeless in this game, and when that Alien pops out at you and there isn’t a damned thing you can do about it, it will make you panic and feel defeated. I really enjoyed going after mission objectives while playing cat and mouse with the Xeno, and trying to out think it. There are more dangers you will face during your time on Sevastopol Station like malfunctioning androids, and stranded colonists that have lost their minds to fear. The station itself is almost a villain in this game as it dark corridors and dim lighted areas will play tricks on your mind. I can’t tell you how many times I thought the Xeno was after me just to be relieved it was some pipes and boxes. Another thing I like in this game is the crafting system and making use of what small of tools you can use to get yourself out of situations, and of course we cannot forget our dumbed down motion tracker that does not work as well as the ones the Marines have in Aliens but next to using your ears, it’s about the only way to know if you are being hunted.  I don’t normally like survival horror games, and I might be biased as I am an Alien fanboy, but this game is a must play, and I would recommend it to anybody. That does not mean it is a perfect game by any stretch. The one fatal flaw of this game is that it is absolutely frustrating at times. I actually have yet to finish it as I am stuck about 60% through the game, and my desire to go on any longer has faded. For one this is 2015… Why the hell do we have such an ancient save system? I understand the save system was to ramp up the difficulty but that should be a choice of players not a developers. They could have implemented a “hardcore” mode that disabled auto saving and what not. It is absolutely just painful to lose so much progress because of a death, for myself that is almost a deal breaker as it just sucks the fun out of the game. Auto saves please! Hopefully somebody will mod it, until then I am not sure if I will go back, it is just too frustrating.  Flaws aside though, this game was a massive leap forward for Alien franchise games. The atmosphere of the game is the real winner here, the lighting is perfect, fire effects are perfect. It really just looks amazing. Also don’t forget to look out the windows of the space station, the view is amazing! I applaud the Creative Assembly team for a job well done. Hopefully this leads to something greater!

The audio (with the exception of the voice acting) is incredible and the lighting is hands down the best I have ever seen in a game period. The Alien 'ai' is really impressive and unpredictable to a point where I stopped getting frustrated about dying and gradually got more and more impressed. Hard to get mad at an enemy when it outsmarts you without feeling cheap. While you can take the offensive strategy with other humans and Working Joes (robots), your only chance with the Alien is to waste resources temporarily causing it to leave or staying invisible. And when it runs away because of your attack you better think of something fast cause it's coming back with an attitude. As an Alien fan this game is also a massive fan service. If you like horror or stealth or the original Alien then this is for you.  9.75/10  Pros:  Lighting Lighting Lighting Unpredictable Xenomorph ai that doesn't feel 'cheap'. Audio Attention to detail staying faithful to the source material. Very few bugs (I experienced none) Game length Story  Cons:  Certain areas (A very small number of them) can feel 'bottlenecked' making progression very difficult due to being forced into a room (Usually to activate a cutscene or something). I'm in love with Alien and I'm in love with this game. It is burdened with its share of problems, some of which may understandably be dealbreakers for certain players.   The game is at its best when it's integrating entirely new challenges with its more familiar threats, but that experience is ocassionally undermined when those allegedly 'new' problems can be easily handled with the tactics you've already used many times. It's more interesting when you're forced to tune your strategy to come up with new solutions, and the game doesn't do that nearly enough.  Also, the cutscenes are kind of a drag. I love when the exposition is handled during first-person gameplay, as it really maintains the game's amazing sense of tension. There's a moment in the game where you experience a flashback by playing through a past event, and it's FANTASTIC. It's really telling that this dramatic change in setting and time feels more organic than the blunt transition into a pre-rendered cutscene.  Overall, though, this game is great. I felt the same sense of fear and urgency in the game's final moments as I did during the initial encounter with the alien. The sound design is unparalleled, the art feels innovative and nostalgic at the same time, and playing at the hardest difficulty actually mitigates many of the problems of repetitive gameplay. And if you love Alien as much as I do, you're kind of required to play this game.

I've never before played a game that made me actually sweat in chair with nervous energy as I crept through a level hoping not to get caught, and while there are a few 'jumpscares' in the game, they are effectively used and fit the atmosphere of the game rather that feeling like a cheap contrivance. So far I'm halfway through Alien Isolation, here are my thoughts: The last time I was so immersed into a game was when I was playing Outlast. Alien Isolation is great! Never do you get the feeling that you need to quit the game before going insane, infact it'll make you want to sacrfice work / study and sleep time just so you can play it more. Although Alien: Isolation is supposed to be a horror game, I find much of it more stressful and nerve wrecking then scary. (In a good way) Quite often you'll be given an objective to trigger some sort of mechanism to continue with the story, but you'll have to travel halfway accross the map with an Alien constantly pursuing you, few save points included. The Alien is almost movie like, its ability to go smoothly into vents, walk, and run without looking like some sort of robot is amazing. Although it looks like an Alien, I was hoping for a more clever behavoir, such as; the ability to learn from its mistakes. For example, I would be limited to the amount of times I can hide in a locker before the Alien learns of what I'm doing and goes around tearing all the lockers down to find me, or, if used enough, the Alien wouldn't fall for the old 'noise maker' routine.  The graphics look amazing, you could almost compare them to the series themselves. But, like all games it has its faults, I've noticed an absence of shadows, especially the one that supposed to be cast by the character herself. I installed a custom mod for better reflections, because before most reflections just looked like sanded glass. The amount of intiqruite detail in the spaceship is a large contributing factor of the immersiveness of the game, you might even think that you're in real life. I would definently recommend this game to anyone. :)

This game is terrifying.  So I'm normally a very conservative player in these types of games. It takes me an hour to go through a tiny village in DayZ because I am always careful, slow and quiet. So it was about 10 hours into this game before I was killed by the Alien. Twice. In the same room.   I'd made it to a telephone after scrambling out of my hiding space. The Alien was down the hallway quite a bit, and after sneaking around it in close quarters for an hour and a half I felt comfortable.  I was horribly naive.  I watched Amanda insert her keycard into the phone. The lights went off signifying the game was saving, blinking off one by one. On the last one, I heard a growl and a shadow cast over me, and my stomach dropped. It had found me.  I was ripped away from the phone and thrown onto the ground, where the Alien met me face to face. In a moment, it was over.  It sounds strange, but the death was oddly satisfying. Stealth games aren't much of a challenge to me anymore because of my aforementioned careful playing style. But this game has ripped the comfort and confidence of my skills from me, throwing me into an environment that is fresh, challenging and genuinely terrifying.  I'm not terrified by zombies anymore, in DayZ or any other game. Nor am I terrified by dinosaurs, monsters or other aliens.  But the developers of this game have made me terrified of the Xenomorph. 11/10, would play again.

Fairly well executed spiritual successor of Alien 1 movie. It is dark, terrifying, slow-paced. The lighting and environments are some of the finest computer generated game graphics I've seen to date. All the visuals serve to keep immersion sky-high. The alien is also gorgeous, and in this game you will see and hear plenty of it.  The immersion is great enough that after a gaming session, all stomping noises in the neighborhood are going to cause you to immediately evaluate your neighborhood for hiding places and figure out where the vents are so you know which places are especially dangerous to be in.  Playstyle is almost completely stealth based. It mostly runs with a few tropes, like being locked in a mazelike environment with the alien with the goal to push various buttons and pull various switches while evading it. There are also stealth sections where the Alien hunts the player but usually doesn't make an appearance unless the player first makes some msitake. Overall, the game is ideal for the patient people who like exclusively stealth-based gamestyle, and have cold, calculating nerves to gauge the risks in a dynamically changing situation, and know how to react. The game is forced into stealth mode because the alien can not be harmed by weapons provided. Nevertheless, there are some fire-based weapons that cause the alien to run away and hide if the player chooses to attack it with them.  I in particular enjoy the hiding-in-the-cabinet mechanic, where it's not enough to just go inside a cabinet to be undetectable. The alien will still hear your breathing unless you choose to hold it (but you can't do it for very long) and may see you if it chooses to peer inside, unless you immediately move further away from the door. These simple devices enhance the stealth experience enormously and keep you at your toes, where other games have erred in making cabinet hiding 100% safe.  The game, unfortunately, suffers from its second half that feel grafted on, on top of almost impeccable beginning. At halfway point, the game starts to get FPS-like elements such as plenty of ammo and enemies you need to shoot with standard gallery of weapons such as pistols and shotguns. Even more worryingly, there is a severe problem with the Alien eggs in this game, which any Aliens fan is sure to notice. There is also no satisfying conclusion, so the narrative just breaks in an obvious DLC/sequel bait. These mistakes significantly degrade the experience. In this reviewer's head-cannon, the game simply ends at its peak on the first half. The rest was simply unnecessary crap piled on top of well thought out and executed sequel/reinvigoration of the alien of the first movie.

An overlong but satisfying survival horror game, Alien: Isolation is the closest a video game has come to capturing the tension of the Alien films since the marine campaign in AvP2.   Playing as Ellen Ripley's daughter, your training as an engineer does little to protect you from the threats you'll face aboard Sevastopol station, so you'll find yourself spending the majority of your time hiding in a closet or sneaking around. I know this may read like a negative but it's a positive; this is the first time in a very long time that a survival horror game has actually felt like it required the use of brains over brawn, the way it should do,  The one and only problem with this title starts to set in about halfway through, when it becomes abundantly clear that the developers ran out of ideas and are artificially padding things out to stall for time. This wouldn't have been too much of a issue if they hadn't overdone it to the degree that they did. No joke, some of the second act and most of the third could have been cut and you'd still have a congruent narrative and well-paced gameplay at the end of it.  As stated, the game's excessive length is the only real issue here and much of the rest of it is flawless. The retro-futuristic stylings mirror those of the original films down to the smallest detail, completely immersing you in their world from the start. The AI has the odd hiccup every now and then but overall it's believable, and hilarious after you learn how to lure the xenomorph into a group of enemies.   One of the most surprisingly great things about A: I, however, is just how well optimised it is. The devs must have a wizard in their team or something, because even on my fairly average PC this runs with max settings across the board without so much as a stutter. Even with its dodgy anti-aliasing, A: I looks eye-poppingly gorgeous in its own dark, dingy sort of way.  If you're a fan of the film Alien or survival horror, this is the best representation of either in years.

Let's start with the easy part: The environments are spectacular. It's a faithful recreation of the style of this first movie, including all 'old style' technologies of the time (displays, tapes, keycards, etc). The sound design is also excellent, from the originals effects to the atmosphere, an essential aspect for stealth games. If you are a fan, there's little more one could ask for.  Now for the gameplay. The alien can't be killed, so you have to always hide from it. Later on (slight spoiler)   you can drive it away with fire, but are still limited by items and ammo  . Direct encounters with it will almost always result in death, so it takes a while for you to learn all the 'tricks' to avoid detection (hint: don't keep using the loud motion tracker while on a closet...). The other category of enemy you will encounter is less fatal and can be dealt with stealth or weapons, so there is a little more variety.  However, It's on the first type of encounter (Alien) that this game will be worth or not. On the harder difficulties in can be somewhat ruthless and the save system - sparse checkpoints or saves at manual stations at specific rooms - can make it very frustrating. There are some cheats on the AI that can be irritating as well, such as the fact that the Alien is always around your location no matter how silent you have been and how far you have traveled. It should be noted that the game does allow you to change difficulty at anytime.  If you can deal with these somewhat frustrating aspects, there is a memorable experience here. There is a lot of tension in moments like hiding from a near Alien, just listening to his steps, or being scared to use the motion tracker because it will give your position away. As with any stealth game, with time you learn the rules and it become less effective, but when it clicks... it's amazing and scaring experience.  --- If you can deal with the buggy and somewhat cheap AI and some frustrating mechanics, this is a gorgeous game, with amazing environments, that can provide some really terrifying moments.

Never was a big fan of horror games until this game. I don't really care for jump scares, they don't really count as scares more like startles. Alien: Isolation is amazing for 2 major reasons:  -The development team did an incredible job designing the levels of the game; it feels like you are in the first film, just set on a larger ship.  -The terror in the game comes from the feeling that the Alien could show up at almost any time. How I Spent My Summer Vacation Aboard Sevastopol Station: Hiding in a locker, under a table, and shooting androids.  This is a completely new kind of game for me, and for all of us. It's similar to Dishonored (which the devs have admitted to gleaning inspiration from) in that it has a lot of the same gameplay mechanics and stealth-emphasis, but unlike Dishonored and Aliens: Colonial Marines (the less said about that game, the better), you're put up against a considerable threat that you can NOT defeat, which I guess is where a lot of the fear comes from.  It's like 'The Ant Bully': 'What'cha gonna do about it, Xeno? Nothing! Because I'm strong, and you're small!'*  Except now the tables have turned. A:CM got us so used to blazing through Aliens, but with this beautiful, horrifying, high-definition monster casually prancing around the station (his walk reminds me of Steve Urkel's; every time he walks past me I want to crank up the tunes and dance with him), it makes you realize how helpless you are, which I suppose is what they keep telling people. It isn't Call of Duty, so if you fancy spitting out as much lead as possible then go play Aliens: Colonial Marines; but if you want to try something different or try and ease into the horror genre - the TRUE horror genre, then this is a good choice. I know a lot of these reviewers always complain about how you 'die all the time', but in all honesty you don't. I'm playing on the hardest difficulty, and although it isn't by any means easy, it's not like the Alien has heat vision or something and can see you hiding in a locker from across the station. Play this game cautiously, don't sprint around, don't act like the lone gunslinger, don't hide in lockers (only use them if you're in an area with absolutely nowhere to hide), and don't get the impression that, 'Oh, I get a gun in this game so that must mean I can pwn the Alien.'  Fellow Aliens fans or people who might get hooked into the fascinating backstory of this franchise also have additional things to be gained, for this game has some really, really interesting elements that it adds to the story. The Arious motion tracker, for example, can actually be seen on advertisements, where its intended usage is in pest control, which makes some sense. So it's just things like that, those little things that make it more fun, and less of a game where, 'Oh, I'm on a random space station and all I have to do is hide from an unkillable Alien, and then I'll win somehow.'  So overall, for fans of this genre and/or series; buy it and you won't have a whiff of regret. For Call of Duty fanboys and people on low-end computers, you almost certainly won't enjoy this. If you decide to disregard a mixture of common sense, your own instinct, and a friendly warning, and you're unhappy with the purchase, then you're idiots.  (*Not an exact quote.)

Played this using the Oculus Rift DK2 and I had a blast. This was easily the most complete VR experience I had so far. Finished the game in about 20 hours because I would seldom pause to look around and admire the finely crafted enviroments.  PROS: - Very detailed world with good ambience, it really feels like you are inside a rundown space station. - The Alien AI got some bashing, but I can say that it always kept me on my toes and posed a good challenged and instilled a sense of dread. The first 20 or so times will really freak you out. - VR implementation was good enough, far from perfect but it shows that the did indeed gave it some love.   CONS: - A bit too long for its own good. By the middle/end of the game it drags a lot, reusing areas, forcing a lot of arbitrary backtracking (There's a scene where you have to run around through the same area back and forth 3 times). It's a bit like Dead Space: you go somewhere to do something, once you get there it doesn't work/it is useless/it's destroyed, so you are rerouted somewhere to do something else which will also not accomplish anything at all. - Gameplay gets a bit repetitive and later you learn how to game the Alien AI and that knowledge combined with the flamethrower makes it become more like a nuisance than a fearless unkillable stalker (granted, it happens after several hours of tense gameplay, so this actually felt like a relief).  Conclusion: If you have a DK2, don't think twice, get this game. Unless you don't like to experience dread and fear in a videogame or you have some serious heart condition.

I have just finished the game, and I am really annoyed at the bullcrap ending, so before I do the negatives I want to run quickly through the positives. This is a beautiful game with amazing modeling, animation, visual effects, sound effects, and to a certain extent story and level design; they are all state of the art, and the people who made them should be proud of the work they did. In the end, however, the game suffers from massive gameplay issues. Weapon selection is a mess, compounded by the decision to have real time pass when you're on the weapon/build menu. Look-at-and-select objects trigger inconsistently, and are often grouped too close together. Quick time events are constantly pulling the player out of immersion, and frequently lock the player into lengthy animations that get them wounded or killed despite no rationale to justify the player being stuck (especially welding and using computers or rewire boxes). The player has no jump button, yet gets stuck on foot-tall ledges or bodies because they are not marked as climbable. There are also several general bugs; characters that wouldn't acknowledge my presence, doors that got stuck in their open position when closed and could not be passed or interacted with, etc. Then there is the ending: you can't win, you can only proceed until the gameplay stops and the credits roll. It was an odd choice, and I'm assuming there is going to be some sort of DLC to resolve this. The biggest problem is that, aside from how amazing this game looks, actually playing it is a stressful chore. I found myself saving obsessively just so I wouldn't have to play a minute longer than I had to to get it done, which pretty much invalidates the reason for buying most of the existing DLC. I give this game 7 out of 10, and I do recommend buying it, but wait until it drops below $30. It took me about 29 hours to finish the game, although I like to explore; this is a pretty good length for a game of this type.

Despite my initial doubts, I give my recommendation to Alien: Isolation with some provisos:  1) Unless you are super good at video games, play it on easy. On hard, you die so much that there's no time for tension to build, and tension is this game's bread and butter. 2) Play it in the dark with headphones. That should be a given for a horror game, but it's worth it, because again, tension. 3) Don't stay up until 1:30 am playing it. Yes, the save points are pretty far apart and you might have to repeat some stuff, but it's just not worth it. 4) Don't go into it expecting anything but what it is: slow, tense, and stealthful. This isn't a shooter, and it isn't (mostly) about jump scares. 5) Make sure you have a copy of your favourite Alien movie (any of them except 4) close at hand, because you're going to want to watch them when you're done. Which is what I am off to do.

The alien universe has had many developements over the years, including the many sequels to the original horror film as well as the many AVP spinoffs. However in my opinion, none has yet matched the original, claustrophobic, and truly terrifying spirit embodied by Alien. This game has taken that spirit to heart in nearly every way, reproducing the smallest details of the original film, but also changing them in the best and most subtle ways to accomodate the change in medium. There is little to explain about the mechanics of the game, other than the simple fact that you are trapped aboard a star freighter similar in design to the Nostromo with the Alien, a motion tracker, and a set of gadgets that ultimately become useless against your biggest threat as it actively learns how you play. This game has all the suspense and atmosphere of Amnesia, fast paced action and thrill of Outlast, and the amazing sci-fi soul that only the alien universe can provide. I promise that if you are a fan of the original film, this game will not disappoint you, and that you will likely die more than once while admiring the detail and atmosphere. But make no mistake, this is a horror game in the spirit of the original film... if you have no desire to feel like a member of the crew of the Nostromo as they are hunted down one by one by an invincible and deadly predator, you had better go with another game.

This is a stealth game. Not a horror game. Tedium aside, my biggest gripe with this game lies in the behaviour of the AI. It enters the same hallways and rooms when you do, it leaves when you do, even when it has no reason to believe you're there. It is perfectly content to waste all its time and attention lingering around you because the devs wanted the alien to be FOCUSED on you. And this is what kills the game for me, because it no longer feels like it's a scary, believable scenario and in the back of my mind, I know the only reason the alien is still here in this area with me and camping the hallway I need to go through is because the invisible hand of the devs said so.   No matter how deceptive or sneaky I am, no matter how much I try to blockade the path behind me, the alien will be magically moved to the next area with me. If you trick the alien into a sealed room, he teleports. If you get on a tram and move to the other side of the station, he'll be back sooner than you know it. If you hide in a locker, the alien that was previous patroling back and forth will now deliberately pass in front of you a few times, excessively posturing as dictated by the devs, even though it has no reason to believe you're there. It's not dramatic, it just reminds you you're playing a video game.  That said, the rest of the game is fantastic. And after a while, you're given enough access to the tools you need to displace that annoying, camping alien (flamethrower, molotov, pipebombs), and the alien actually GOES AWAY. What a difference it makes, when you can actually explore the rooms (as long as you're walking) and immerse yourself. The game really picks up after the first third or so, I guess when the devs realised they could stop flaunting the alien garishly.  Edit: It'd be nice if the game actually told you how some things worked. Hacking minigames arent explained, but once you figure it out, they're braindead easy. The motion tracker has a bar that doesn't point you towards your objective, but rather towards the path of your objective. It also displays a number in the corner from 0-1.0 that represents range to closest target, so you know if targets are approaching or retreating from you, even if you are not facing them. And don't try to be too cautious otherwise you'll miss your window of escape. Taking risks is a lot easier than being too slow and safe and if you get into trouble, crouching behind any corner or boxes or a low desk is enough, and there are plenty of supplies for crafting so don't try to save your molotovs/noisemakers.

Basically, if you like survival horror, play this game. If you like any of the Alien movies, play this game. If you like both those things...how have you not already played this game!?  Alien: Isolation perfectly captures the atmosphere of the original Alien movie with its claustrophobic design, gorgeous style and very well done audio design. The gameplay only reinforces this by making you constantly feel helpless even when it throws a multitude of craftable items and weapons your way to assist. The encounters with humans can turn into frantic shootouts, the 'Working Joe' androids who patrol the station will bash you to pieces and, oh, then there's the xenomorph!  Having the actions of the lone alien persuing you through the station comletely dictated by an A.I, instead of relying on scripted segments, adds a constant tension to every second of the game. You never know when the xenomorph will show up, what actions will attract it, or where it will go once it begins the hunt. Moments where humans enemies and the xenomorph both converge on you are also a thing of horrifying beauty ;D  Only downsides to Alien: Isolation are a disgustingly long run time (my first playthrough clocked almost 50 hours of me faffing about and dying repeatedly), some wonky bugs in the physics engine and a hard save system without checkpoints. None of these really get in the way of the enjoyment, though and I would say the weak, self conscious plot is the only downside. It doesn't add a whole lot to the canon or building its cardboard characters up.

This game captures both the feeling of the original movie and the sense of dread and helplessness spot on. I usually view myself as an pretty jaded gamer that can go through most horror games without even flinching or watch an 'oh-so-scary' horror movie and find myself bored out of my skull.  But this game... It really managed to make me feel small, helpless, vulnerable and scared. There was a couple of times I found myself watching over my own shoulder just to make sure that there was nothing behind me and what I had just heard really just was the sound from the game. Or as I said to one of my friends after my first encounter with the titular creature: 'This game is not okay! Like, at all! WHY did I buy this!? WHY did I spend money on something that scares me ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥!?' If you have the PC to run it, Alien: Isolation is a terrifyingly awesome experience that is definitely worth trying out. The atmospheric setting, remarkably accurate sound design, and loyalty to the franchise they're based off of makes it a must own for any fan of the Alien series, and is a very welcomed change from the dreadful Aliens: colonial marines, however the game has several issues that hold it back from it's full potential, and while they don't take too much away from the overall experience they're worth mentioning.   +Very loyal to the Alien franchise, the first movie in particular.  +Perfectly terrifying sound design +Great soundtrack that feels as if ripped straight from the movies.  +Insight to what happened between the first and second alien movie that fits well and doesn't completely break the lore like Colonial Marines did. +Absolutely terrifying +I personally think it's a good thing in a survival horror game to have an enemy that constantly pursues you, and you having no way to actually kill it, only the drive it away for a few brief moments.  +Equipment is precious, and you are often forced to save it for dire moments +The game balances the need to scavenge and the need to progress pretty well. Sure you want that blueprint, but the alien is right down the hallway and your green blooper is blooping really hard. +Combat is always a last resort. The game tries to force you to play terribly cautiously, and while combat can save your life short-term it can also be a death sentence.  +Difficult, like any horror game should be. This game is best experienced on the highest difficulty, even though sometimes you might be forced to turn it down a notch. +Insightful collectables to find +Survival mode is pretty fun and stressful considering you are not only scared to death, but only have moments to complete your objective.  +Graphics are alright, could have been better +this game would be ♥♥♥♥ing perfect for VR  -Weird occasional performance issues/crashes -Lip syncing is way off. Easy to notice towards the start, but becomes a forgetable issue.  -Character movements are kind of stiff and awkward -The middle part of the game is undoubtably the worst part, simply because the threat of the alien vanishes temporarily. I won't lie; the androids are fun to fight, but it starts to feel like a dumbed down action game rather than a classy survival-horror game.  -You are forced to backtrack a lot of the ship rather than explore the whole thing which is dissapointing, but the game keeps you fixed on your objective area well despite you having free roam. -The ending to the game's story is a huge sequel baiter, and doesn't make any real sense. Kind of disappointing   In conclusion Alien Isolation is an amazing game, IGN is full of ♥♥♥♥ giving this game a 5/10, that wasn't even a review it was more like an informal grievance to sega and creative assembly asking them to pay for a review next time. The Atmosphere is spot on, it's intense and does service to the series it came from. 8/10

I will keep this review brief and focus on what I think are this games two big selling points.  1) If you are a fan of the movie Alien (Note, Alien, not aliens), then this is the true spiritual successor to that movie. It looks like Alien, it feels like Alien. The attention to detail is stunning, that strange 70/80's take on scifi and what the future will look like. Computer run like they are on dos, monitors are big and chunky. The developers of this game clearly had a lot of love for the alien film, nothing this atmospheric could have come from anyone else.  2) The alien. I don't think there's a more contentious point about this game than the Alien, and the A.I of the Alien. I won't go into what I think on that, but I will state the one thing I think that makes it a success, it's randomness. With most other horror games, like Amnesia and Outlast, you can look up where the enemies are and get strategies on how to get past them. That's not the case with AI, you can never be sure where the Alien is, you can never be sure when it's going to come down. You can certainly learn coping mechanisms and get experienced in using your gadgets, but ultimately it is all about skill. No guide can help you with this, and that makes for a hell of an experience.

The game that finally does the Alien franchise justice and delivers a gripping, innovative gameplay experience the likes of which I have never seen before. This is a rare example of a movie licensed game that gets it right.   Just as James Cameron took the Alien franchise to another level, Creative Assembly have taken this franchise to another level on a different medium. I have never played a game like this where the creature hunts you down and it's A.I. is superb. You never know when it will arrive and when it does, you have to be truly stealthy and watch your every move. Other stealth games have the npc's walking predictable routes but the alien is truly life like with its movements and spontaneity.  The sound design is second to none. I played this on a pc with a good stereo system but I can only imagine in surround sound what it would be like. I'm thinking of playing again on the PS4 just to use the surround system. The sounds are true to the movies but also have new ones that fit in seamlessly. Stealth games live and die on the sound design and this game got it just right. The movie quality music is dynamic and changes with the action in the game which brings the tension to even stronger heights.  The level design is varied and spectacular. Even though its mainly on a space station, they gave each mission different objectives and variation to always feel fresh. I never got bored. It constantly threw new things at me and changed up the scenario.   The graphics are gorgeous. This game looks so good. I took over a 100 screenshots through my playthrough as I marvelled at the detail and design of the space station. Props from the movie are placed throughout and add a nostalgaic value to an already fantastic game. The engine is also very well optimized as not once during my entire playthrough did I see a frame drop.  The constant threat of the alien is what makes this game so great. The design and animation of the alien brings it to life and I cannot say enough good things. This is the game that Alien fans have been waiting for and I'm so glad that Creative Assembly knocked it out of the park with this one. The love of the franchise permeates every aspect of this game. This great work cannot have been done without an avid passion for this universe.   Bravo.

In Alien: Isolation, you are in the shoes of Amanda Ripley, a young engineer on a quest to learn more about her mother in a decommissionned space station... which rapidly turns into a game of cat and mouse between you (the mouse) and various lethal dangers. This is probably one of the best survival horror games released in the last few years.  First of all, the setting is incredible, Creative Assembly went the extra mile in recreating the retrofuturistic look of the first two Alien movies when they meticulously crafted Sevastopol station. Every little maintenance panel covered with blinking buttons and every piece of dated yet advanced technology will remind you of the original films. The soundtrack is very much inspired by the film scores, and all the noises, from the creaking bulkheads of the station to the hiss of the alien, will quickly immerse you in an uneasy atmosphere. If you're a fan, you will be absolutely delighted by this fact alone. The director of the soon-to-be-released Alien 5 movie (Neil Blomkamp) actually referenced this game in an interview, saying the artists blew his mind and made him reconsider what he wants his movie to look like.  The gameplay is also a work of art. Where some survival horror games remove weapons from you to make you feel powerless and heighten stress (SOMA, Amnesia, etc.), this one actually gives you a small arsenal of more or less effective guns and melee weapons to use. You might think this trivializes content, and sometimes it does, but there are some threats you will definitely not be able to eliminate through force. Namely, a ruthless alien which will constantly hunt you throughout the game. Where it can end your life swiftly, you are very much limited in what you can do to fight back. Fire will keep it at bay for a short time, flashbangs will stun it, smoke grenades will disorient it, noise will distract it... but you will never be able to kill it.  Another place where Alien: Isolation innovates is the actual AI of the Alien. On higher difficulties, it is hard to predict, and really knows how to keep you on your toes. You will have to adapt your strategies throughout the game as it becomes more aggressive.  The technical aspect is really good as well; textures are high resolution and lighting effects are top notch. The modeling of the enemies is great and the performance is outstanding.   Some drawbacks that professionnal reviewers might point out include the amount of backtracking and the pacing of the game. To me, these were really minor issues, if at all. The backtracking is always justified, and helped make me feel like I was really stuck on this nightmarish station, making my way through the maze of corridors to survive. Besides, the game does a good job of letting you discover new areas in old zones thanks to a set of tools that allow you to progressively open more doors as you upgrade them. As for the pacing, I welcomed sections where the Alien took a backseat. Typically, it was in these parts of the game that I took more time to take in my surroundings, listen to audio tapes, read the information on the public terminals... and there are other dangers than just the Alien in this game.  Overall, Alien: Isolation deserves its place among the greats of the survival horror genre. Creative Assembly did an outstanding job and I can only hope for a sequel to this game.

Overall, it was a beautiful and explorative atmosphere experience that was okay for me, but not for everyone.

I found this to be incredibly annoying and immersionp ruining, so I stopped playing it only after an hour or so.   I recently bought the game again on PC during the Steam Winter Sale in the hopes of better performance. Obviously, due to the massively better specs of my PC and laptop over my PS4 (i7 3770k and i76700HQ respectively, both with GTX 1070s and >16GB RAM running on Windows 10) the game looks gorgeous and runs at a stable 60FPS at 1080p.   The reason I cannot recommend this game is that even after two full years of massive performance issues on the PC related to crashes, the developer has not yet been able to fix the issue. Many of the fixes for this game involve editing Steam files, fiddling with languages, or turning off odd combinations of graphical settings - none of these options have worked for me. I'm currently at 60 minutes played, but I'm barely past the 15 minute mark due to how many times my game has crashed and I have had to restart while trouble shooting the problems.  So far the crashes I have experience have been:  1) Crashing before loading a save; 2) Crashing after leaving a specific room early in the game; and 3) Crashing after climbing down a ladder in the above mentioned room.  I understand that different hardware and software configurations can throw a wrench in a games performance, but after two solid years of opportunity to fix the multiple issues that are game breaking and seemingly nigh impossible to solve, I can't in good faith recommend this title.  This game has received excellent reviews from multiple sites and users, but those were the lucky ones who magically had the game work for them without issue; suffered through frame rate and graphical issues on consoles; or spent the ridiculous amount of time and effort trouble shooting it on their PC. Unless you're willing to put in the hours of trouble shooting, or are just feeling lucky, I recommend you steer clear of this game, or at the very least ensure you don't exceed the 2 hour mark so you can refund after the inevitable game breaking bugs.
